Award.AwardTitle: Spectroscopic and Computational Mapping of Biological and Biomimetic Hydrogenase Mechanisms

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-0755676
Szilagyi

The proposed research directly addresses the objectives of the Catalysis and Biocatalysis program by defining the molecular basis of biological hydrogen production and utilization with potentials for providing breakthroughs in non-fossil dihydrogen production. We will develop quantitative structure and activity relationships (QSAR) for FeFe-hydrogenases and related structurally and/or functionally analogous models. We will locate the intermediates and transition states on the potential energy surface of the biological hydrogen metabolism using spectroscopically calibrated computational tools. The virtual molecular models to be developed will define the molecular mechanisms of the hydrogen uptake and evolution processes. We will impact the rationalized design and optimization of novel compounds that mimic the efficient active site of the FeFe-hydrogenases (H-cluster).

A unique aspect of the research approach is the innovative integration of experimental techniques (multi-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure, XANES, and Extended X-ray fine structure, EXAFS, analyses) and theoretical methods (multi-layered density functional/molecular orbital/molecular mechanical computations, DFT/MO/MM). Our combined spectroscopic (in lumeno) and computational (in silico) approach that results in the spectroscopic calibration of modern density functional theory are essential for increasing the reliability of in silico models in predicting catalytic function. Specifically, we aim to

- understand the role and importance of the biologically unique, organometallic ligand environment of the H-cluster, as one of the most efficient, non-noble metal-based catalysts for hydrogen evolution and utilization, by defining the fundamental electronic structure properties that determine the H-cluster?s stability and catalytic activity;

- eliminate the uncertainties in iron oxidation states, carbonyl vs. cyanide coordination, composition of the dithiolate cofactor, electronic connection within the active site clusters of FeFe-hydrogenases from green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii by XANES and EXAFS;

- develop realistic in silico models for a 10-15 Ã… environment of the H-cluster and the accessory iron-sulfur clusters by employing DFT/MO/MM integrated theory for mapping the potential energy surface of hydrogen evolution and uptake, and dissecting how the protein environment tunes the structure, redox potential, and protonation of various sites that leads to the high catalytic activity.

In addition to the discovery of fundamental physico-chemical properties of structure, stability, and reactivity of the highly optimized hydrogenase active site, our biophysical and computational method development will very likely influence research into other iron-sulfur containing metalloenzymes. The PI's expertise in computational chemistry and X-ray absorption spectroscopy and the collaborators' backgrounds create a multidisciplinary research environment for scientific discovery and student training. The PI's students will learn the fine details of sample preparations from collaborators; conversely, the PI will host the collaborators' students at the XAS beamlines. The PI is committed to training undergraduate and graduate students in computational chemistry and spectroscopy. He maintains an up-to-date website for efficiently disseminating his research, teaching, and software/hardware engineering activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The hydrogenases form a unique group of metalloenzymes that are responsible for the reversible conversion of protons and electrons to hydrogen gas in biology. The research funded by NSF CBET program focused on their most active members, the FeFe-hydrogenases and their biomimetic complexes. In our research, we utilized a symbiotic approach of chemical synthesis, spectroscopic measurements, and theoretical modeling (Figure 1) to dissect the structural elements of the FeFe-hydrogenase catalytic active site, H-cluster (see Figure 2). In addition to the Fe-S cluster’s remarkable catalytic activity (approx. 9000 molecules of hydrogen gas per second per enzyme molecule), its chemical composition is also quite unique. The presence of normally biotoxic cyanide and carbonmonoxide ligands is limited to the hydrogenase metalloenzymes. Therefore, in parallel to the chemical structure and reactivity relationship studies, we were also involved in figuring out the tantalizing biochemical synthetic pathway of the H-cluster components.

Scientific Impact:

The initial work focused on one of the last unknowns of FeFe-hydrogenase, which are the chemical composition of the dithiolate ligand. This is an important aspect of the composition of the catalytic H-cluster, since it has been proposed that depending on its composition it can greatly affect chemical reactivity. The scientific community must eliminate this uncertainty before we can really understand how simple Fe-S-based compounds can perform such a remarkable chemical reactivity. From mainly computational modeling, but critically guided by experimental data from collaborators laboratories we presented an unbiased approach to evaluating all possible chemical compositions using close to atomic resolution, protein crystallographic data, information about biosynthetic pathways, our own X-ray absorption spectroscopic measurements, and a comprehensive density-functional theory based modeling we compiled support for dithiomethylether being the elusive dithiolate ligand. This composition vs. the dithiomethylamine can open up a new family of biomimetic complexes (Figure 3), with the possibility of better mimicking the chemical reactivity of the metalloenzyme.

The main body of the work was focused on synthesis, spectroscopic, and computational characterization of a family of biomimetic complexes (Figure 4). Using a series of 2Fe clusters with various thiol, carbonmonoxide, cyanide, phosphine ligands we were evaluate five structural features: i) bridging vs. terminal sulfur ligands, ii) length of the bridging sulfur ligands, iii) composition of the sulfur ligands, iv) ligand effects of carbonmonoxide, cyanide, phosphine, thioether, v) redox state. Using a multi-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopic method, which is defined by conscious over-definition of the complexes electronic structure from Fe, S, C, and O core electron ionization measurements (Figure 5), we quantitatively determined the effect of all the above structural features that can be considered as design parameters for generating functionally better analogous to the H-cluster than the currently know biomimetic complexes.

Another key finding of our detailed computational work on the electronic structure is how important the presence of both subclusters of the H-cluster. From a systematic electronic structure analysis (Figure 6) we mapped out the network of interactions within and between the [4Fe-4S] and [2Fe]-subclusters of H-cluster. The detailed density functional analysis explained several experimental observations from the literature and parallel posed some questions to some of the interpretations.
